title: How to Sew Fun Pockets for the Kids

steps.headline: Gather your garment, scraps of fabric and other sewing supplies.
steps.description: This technique requires plenty of thread.

steps.headline: Cut the fabric into fun shapes, such as a circle, star, heart, cloud, animal or random shape.
Cut iron-on interfacing into the same shape as your pocket.
Iron the interfacing to the wrong side of your fabric.
Use a second small strip of iron-on interfacing along the opening of the pocket.
steps.description: This will add more support to the fabric.

steps.headline: Using a straight stitch, carefully stitch along the edge of the opening of the pocket.
Using a tight zig zag stitch, stitch over the straight stitching.
steps.description: This will help to keep the fabric from fraying.

steps.headline: Align and pin your pocket onto your garment.
Using a straight stitch, carefully stitch the remaining sides of the pocket onto the garment.
steps.description: Place the stitch close to the edge of the pocket.

steps.headline: Using a tight zig zag stitch, stitch over the straight stitching, encasing the raw edges of your pocket.
Trim away any tiny frays of fabric that may have formed around the zig zag stitching.
steps.description: If you accidentally cut the stitching, the next step will help to mend it.

steps.headline: Add a wider zig zag stitch over the previous zig zag stitch.

text: Gather your garment, scraps of fabric and other sewing supplies. This technique requires plenty of thread. Cut the fabric into fun shapes, such as a circle, star, heart, cloud, animal or random shape.  Cut iron-on interfacing into the same shape as your pocket.  Iron the interfacing to the wrong side of your fabric.  Use a second small strip of iron-on interfacing along the opening of the pocket. This will add more support to the fabric. Using a straight stitch, carefully stitch along the edge of the opening of the pocket.  Using a tight zig zag stitch, stitch over the straight stitching. This will help to keep the fabric from fraying. Align and pin your pocket onto your garment.  Using a straight stitch, carefully stitch the remaining sides of the pocket onto the garment. Place the stitch close to the edge of the pocket. Using a tight zig zag stitch, stitch over the straight stitching, encasing the raw edges of your pocket.  Trim away any tiny frays of fabric that may have formed around the zig zag stitching. If you accidentally cut the stitching, the next step will help to mend it. Add a wider zig zag stitch over the previous zig zag stitch.
